metadata.case_name: Express Newspapers (Private) Ltd. v. Union of India & Others
metadata.case_number: Writ Petition No. 91 of 1957 & connected petitions

facts.text: Newspaper industry in India originally started as individual newspapers founded by leaders but developed into profit-making industry with big industrialists investing and combines controlling several newspapers.
Working journalists agitated for impartial agency to fix wages, salaries, dearness allowance, retirement benefits, leave and conditions of service.
Uttar Pradesh Government appointed committee on June 18, 1947 to enquire into conditions of work of newspaper employees; reported on March 31, 1949.
Government of Central Provinces Berar appointed Inquiry Committee on March 27, 1948; reported on March 27, 1948.
Prime Minister indicated during Parliament debates in 1951 appointment of committee or commission to examine state of Press.
Indian Federation of Working Journalists adopted resolution in April 1952 for Press Commission.
Government announced Press Commission on September 23, 1952 under Chairmanship of Shri Justice G. S. Rajadhyaksha; reported on July 14, 1954.
Press Commission found only 59 of 137 concerns profitable; recommended minimum wage of Rs. 125 basic + Rs. 25 DA; proof-readers as working journalists in certain cases.
Parliament passed Working Journalists Industrial Disputes Act, 1955 (I of 1955) on March 12, 1955 applying Industrial Disputes Act to working journalists.

Union Government introduced Bill No. 13 of 1955 on November 30, 1955 leading to Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955) assented December 20, 1955.

Act defines working journalist including proof-reader; applies Industrial Disputes Act with modifications; provides gratuity, hours of work (144 hrs/4 weeks), leave; constitutes Wage Board under s.8; s.9 criteria for wages.
Central Government notified Working Journalists Wage Board Rules, 1956 on July 30, 1956.
Wage Board constituted May 2, 1956 with Chairman Shri H.V. Divatia and 3 employer reps, 3 journalist reps.
Shri K.P. Kesava Menon resigned June 21, 1956; replaced by Shri K.M. Cherian July 14, 1956.
Board issued questionnaire to 5465 newspapers; only 381 responded.
Board held meetings in various zones Sept 1956 to April 1957; recorded evidence.
Board decisions April 1957: classified newspapers by gross revenue A-E; employees Groups I-IV; wage scales by class/group; DA, allowances; retrospective from 1956; majority decisions on key points.
Employers' minute of dissent: wages based on capacity to pay, industry nature; proposals too high, risk closures.
Chairman note: fixed on industry average, not individual; review after 3-5 years.
Wage Board decision published May 11, 1957.
Petitions filed: WP 91/1957 by Express Newspapers June 13, 1957; others in Aug-Sept 1957 challenging Act and Wage Board.
Express Group: 331 working journalists; wage bill increase Rs.5.43 lakhs annual + arrears Rs.5.16 lakhs.
Press Trust of India: 170 working journalists; increase Rs.4.05 lakhs annual + arrears.
Similar financial burdens detailed for Free Press Group, Saurashtra Trust, Hindustan Times, smaller papers.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 violates Articles 19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14, and 32 of the Constitution.
Validity of Wage Board decision: competence to fix scales, retrospective effect, classification, financial impact.

petitioner_arguments.text: Act violates Art.19(1)(a) freedom of speech and Art.19(1)(g) right to carry on trade or business; also Art.14 equality and Art.32.
Wage Board decision imposes excessive burden leading to collapse; incompetent to fix scales/pay; unfair classification of chains/groups; retrospective effect unfair.
Fixation should consider capacity to pay, not needs alone; risk of closures harming employment and freedom of expression.

respondent_arguments.text: No violation of Arts.19(1)(a), 19(1)(g), 14, 32; Wage Board function legislative, not judicial/quasi-judicial.
Board considered s.9 criteria, material/evidence; many unanimous decisions; competent for scales/retrospective.
Petitioners' financial position not leading to collapse.

court_reasoning.text: Detailed history traced to appreciate contentions; Press Commission recommended wages, legislation followed.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agitation by journalists led to impartial machinery for wage fixation.

court_reasoning.text: Wage Board proceedings fair: questionnaire, evidence, deliberations; majority decisions valid per rules.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unanimous on classifications; majority on wages/scales.

court_reasoning.text: Principles of wage fixation: living wage, fair wage, minimum wage; cited international examples.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Minimum wage tempered by capacity, but provides for efficiency.

precedents_cited.case_name: V. N. N. Sinha v. Bihar Journals Limited
precedents_cited.relevance: Working journalists not workmen under Industrial Disputes Act pre-1955.

precedents_cited.case_name: Harvester case (Australian Commonwealth Court of Conciliation)
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of living wage: appropriate for normal needs of average employee.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Petitions under Art.32; challenged for violating freedoms and equality.

statutes_cited.name: Working Journalists Conditions of Service and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955 (45 of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: Impugned Act regulating wages, gratuity, hours, leave via Wage Board.

statutes_cited.name: Working Journalists Industrial Disputes Act, 1955 (1 of 1955)
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied Industrial Disputes Act to journalists; repealed by 45/1955.

key_quotes.text: "A journalist occupies a responsible position in life and has powers which he can wield for good or evil. It is he who reflects and moulds public opinion."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Press Commission characterization justifying special wage treatment.

key_quotes.text: "Though the living wage is the target, it has to be tempered... by the general level of wages in other industries and the capacity of the industry to pay."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Press Commission on minimum wage concept.

key_quotes.text: "We do not consider it a matter of regret if our decisions discourage the entry into this industry of persons without the necessary resources required for the payment of a reasonable minimum wage."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Chairman note prioritizing journalists over under-resourced papers.
